provenance.name: Cumberland Papers
provenance.note: George Cumberland; bequeathed to his son, George Cumberland; presented to the British Library in 1849, as part of the Cumberland Papers consisting of thirty-one volumes and two rolls, on condition that these should not be opened until 1900.

desc.objtitle: I am very much obliged by your kind ardourLetter to George Cumberland, 19 December 1808, object 1

objnote.p: The letter was written on both sides of a single leaf. Blake's letter is a reply to Cumberland's letter of 18 December 1808, which is available through the Index of Letters.
On the upper right corner of object 1, the British Library folio number, "314", is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.

lg.l: Dear Cumberland
I am very much obliged by your kind ardour in my

cause & should immediately Engage in reving my formerBentley (Writings volume 2, page 1644) reads the uncertain word in this line as "reviewing"; Erdman (page 769) and Keynes (Letters, page 137) read "reviving".
pursuits of printing if I had not now so long been turned
out of the old channel into a new one that it is impossible for
me to return to it without destroying my present course
New vanities or rather new pleasures occupy my thoughts
New profits seem to arise before me so tempting that I
have already involved myself in engagements that preclude all
possibility of promising any thing. I have however the
satisfaction to inform you that I have Myself begun to
print an account of my various Inventions in Art ^ which
I have procured a Publisher & am determined to pursue
the plan of publishing what I may get printed without
disarranging my time which in future must alone be
devoted to Designing & Painting alone when I have gotBentley (Writings volume 2, page 1645) and Erdman (page 770) read the deleted word as "alone"; Keynes (Letters, page 137) does not comment.
my Work printed I will send it you first of any body

objnote.p: The letter was written on both sides of a single leaf. Blake's letter is a reply to Cumberland's letter of 18 December 1808, which is available through the Index of Letters.
Near the center of the top half of object 2 a small red "British Museum" stamp is visible.

lg.l: in the mean time believe me to be
Your Sincere Friend
19 Decr 1808Will Blake
